subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: ... yeah, I don t see much problem with them also, that why I said aim rather than must etc... ... which is what I was trying to say, thanks for rewording.
messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:

>>Aside from this, having multiple assertions within a single test is
>>actually the problem - you want to be aiming for one assertion per
>>test, not multiple.
>>
>>
>
>Well, personally I don't see any problems with more than one assertion per
>test, if the assertions are highly interrelated.
>
>
>

yeah, I don't see much problem with them also, that why I said 'aim'
rather than 'must' etc...

>I agree, though, that the desire to have a test continue after a failed
>assertion is an indicator of tests that test to much at once.
>
>
>
which is what I was trying to say, thanks for rewording.

The typical tests where I'd strongly recommend separate tests, is when
testing something with different values. This allows us to see in a
simple test run, which values don't work with the code under test.

I'd either have separate named tests or use the Parameterized Test Case
pattern.

>Cheers, Ilja
>
>
>
>

Cheers

Andrew
